name: regrant
content:
Add to word list
Add to word list
to give or allow someone something, for a second, third, etc. time, usually in an official way: The agreement included the expectation that the king would regrant what he had revoked. A fortnight later, the company was re-granted an export licence.
More examplesFewer examplesIn 1867, the charter was regranted to him.They are required to request to be re-granted the privilege of using the software.If the planning permission lapses, there is no certainty that it will be re-granted.

an occasion when someone is given or allowed something for a second, third, etc. time, usually in an official way: They need to strike a bargain over the promised regrant. As far as the termination and re-grant of a franchise is concerned, their decision is final.
More examplesFewer examplesA holder may, upon expiration of the initial grant lease term, apply for a re-grant.Included in the category of permissible acts are certain regrants of various leases.There is, however, a provision for a re-grant.
